defs.name: PeekableReader
defs.docs:
from https://github.com/C4K3/peekable-reader-rs/blob/master/src/lib.rs
 A wrapper around any struct implementing the `Read` trait, additionally
 allowing for `peek` operations to be performed. Therefore, the
 `PeekableReader` struct also implements the `Read` trait.

attributes.value: / A wrapper around any struct implementing the `Read` trait, additionally
/ allowing for `peek` operations to be performed. Therefore, the
/ The primary invariant of the `PeekableReader` is that after calling the
/ `peek` method, the next `read_byte` call will return the same result as
/ the `peek` does. When the result is a byte (read off the wrapped reader),
/ any read-type method of the `Reader` trait will include the byte as the
/ first one. On the other hand, if the result is an `io::Error`, the error
/ will be returned regardless of which read-type method of the `Reader` is
/ invoked. Consecutive `peek`s before any read-type operation is used
/ When using peek_u8 you will get a Result<u8, &Error>, while when you call
/ any of the `Read` functions you will get an io::Result<u8>, thereby

defs.name: Peekable
defs.docs:
A wrapper around any struct implementing the `Read` trait, additionally
 allowing for `peek` operations to be performed. Therefore, the
 `PeekableReader` struct also implements the `Read` trait.

defs.name: peek_u8
defs.docs:
When using peek_u8 you will get a Result<u8, &Error>, while when you call
 any of the `Read` functions you will get an io::Result<u8>, thereby
 consuming the io::Error (if any.)

attributes.value: / When using peek_u8 you will get a Result<u8, &Error>, while when you call
/ any of the `Read` functions you will get an io::Result<u8>, thereby

defs.name: peek_u8
defs.docs:
Returns the `io::Result` which the Reader will return on the next
 `get_byte` call.

attributes.value: / Returns the `io::Result` which the Reader will return on the next
/ If the `io::Result` is indeed an `io::Error`, the error will be returned
/ for any subsequent read operation invoked upon the `Read`er.

defs.name: new
defs.docs:
Initializes a new `PeekableReader` which wraps the given underlying
 reader.

defs.name: SerializationError
defs.value: SerializationError::{InvalidOpCode, NotImplementedOpCode, InvalidTypePrefix, VlqEncode, Io, Misc, NotImplementedYet}

defs.name: sigma_serialize
defs.docs:
Write `self` to the given `writer`.
 This function has a `sigma_` prefix to alert the reader that the
 serialization in use is consensus-critical serialization    
 Notice that the error type is [`std::io::Error`]; this indicates that
 serialization MUST be infallible up to errors in the underlying writer.
 In other words, any type implementing `SigmaSerializable`
 must make illegal states unrepresentable.

attributes.value: / This function has a `sigma_` prefix to alert the reader that the
/ serialization in use is consensus-critical serialization
/ Notice that the error type is [`std::io::Error`]; this indicates that
/ serialization MUST be infallible up to errors in the underlying writer.
/ In other words, any type implementing `SigmaSerializable`

defs.name: WriteSigmaVlqExt
defs.docs:
Write encoded unsigned values using VLQ and signed values first with ZigZag, then using VLQ
 for VLQ see [[https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Variable-length_quantity]]
 for ZigZag see https://developers.google.com/protocol-buffers/docs/encoding#types

attributes.value: / Write encoded unsigned values using VLQ and signed values first with ZigZag, then using VLQ

defs.name: ReadSigmaVlqExt
defs.docs:
Read and decode values using VLQ (+ ZigZag for signed values) encoded and written with [`WriteSigmaVlqExt`]
 for VLQ see [[https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Variable-length_quantity]]
 for ZigZag see https://developers.google.com/protocol-buffers/docs/encoding#types

attributes.value: / Read and decode values using VLQ (+ ZigZag for signed values) encoded and written with [`WriteSigmaVlqExt`]

defs.name: encode_i32
defs.docs:
Encode a 32-bit value with ZigZag. ZigZag encodes signed integers
 into values that can be efficiently encoded with VLQ. (Otherwise,
 negative values must be sign-extended to 64 bits to be varint encoded,
 thus always taking 10 bytes on the wire.)
 see https://developers.google.com/protocol-buffers/docs/encoding#types

attributes.value: / Encode a 32-bit value with ZigZag. ZigZag encodes signed integers
/ into values that can be efficiently encoded with VLQ. (Otherwise,
/ negative values must be sign-extended to 64 bits to be varint encoded,
/ thus always taking 10 bytes on the wire.)

defs.name: decode_u32
defs.docs:
Decode a signed value previously ZigZag-encoded with [`encode_i32`]
 see https://developers.google.com/protocol-buffers/docs/encoding#types

attributes.value: / Decode a signed value previously ZigZag-encoded with [`encode_i32`]

defs.name: encode_i64
defs.docs:
Encode a 64-bit value with ZigZag. ZigZag encodes signed integers
 into values that can be efficiently encoded with varint. (Otherwise,
 negative values must be sign-extended to 64 bits to be varint encoded,
 thus always taking 10 bytes on the wire.)
 see https://developers.google.com/protocol-buffers/docs/encoding#types

attributes.value: / Encode a 64-bit value with ZigZag. ZigZag encodes signed integers
/ into values that can be efficiently encoded with varint. (Otherwise,
/ negative values must be sign-extended to 64 bits to be varint encoded,
/ thus always taking 10 bytes on the wire.)

 see https://developers.google.com/protocol-buffers/docs/encoding#types
